text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new self-titled
Beyonce album beyonce is a famed aren't
he and pop singer who through her solo
LPS and her year she put in with
Destiny's Child is one of the most
widely known singers ever and her
biggest records played a large role in
shaping the sound of mainstream
commercial radio friendly R&B throughout
the late 90s and 2000's and unless
you've been living under a rock I'm sure
you know how a lot of these records
sound instrumentally very clean punchy
immediate the most important elephant
being of course Beyonce's incredibly
bold and powerful voice especially on
some of her biggest singles like crazy
and love and single ladies run the world
you're replaceable there's a lot of them
honestly I'm not really here to hold
your hand through a bunch of stuff that
you already know and music that you may
or may not have grown up with all I can
really say is that outside of the
singles I've been pretty neutral on
Beyonce for a majority of her career
however I was pleasantly surprised by a
lot of songs on her last full-length LP
for an LP where I actually thought she
eased up a bit on the surface level
immediate commercial appeal of her music
and started favoring instrumentals that
were a lot more dynamic and I basically
went into this new LP of hers hoping
that she would venture further outside
of that radio-friendly comfort zone and
sort of throw off the pressure to
essentially make an album full of radio
songs and that's kind of been a
recurring theme with a lot of popular
albums from this past year and this
whole I'm not making songs for the radio
mantra has been kind of a recurring
theme with a lot of artists over the
past year Kanye jay-z Drake these
artists and artists like these dropping
more experimental records ethereal
records and specifically in the case of
jay-z relying more on YouTube
advertisements and the buzz surrounding
a deal he did with Samsung to buy so
many copies of his album and then
distribute it to their users and Beyonce
in a similar fashion as well didn't
really do any teasing with the music
toward the release of this new album of
her she just pooted out toward the tail
end of last year and
allowed everybody to hear for the first
time all together at once and obviously
putting her album out this way subtracts
radio promotion from the equation when
it comes to building to your new
full-length album but I think people are
a little quick to jump the gun and just
outright praise her simply for that on
this LP it's not like Beyonce didn't
have successful singles in 2013 it's not
like she didn't have a stunning Super
Bowl performance last year plus her
album was plastered all over the front
of iTunes the day that it dropped which
caused the internet to spread the word
like wildfire considering Beyonce's
young listening audience which is most
likely very deeply linked into the
internet I don't really know if you need
much more promotion these days however
right now it has been a handful of weeks
since this LP originally dropped a lot
of the hype surrounding it has already
dissipated a little bit and it seems
that beyonce and her label aren't really
looking to get into any huge advertising
campaign to ram the album down people's
throats in the coming weeks and this
slightly unorthodox approach for beyonce
is also reflected in the direction she
takes the music into she has over an
hour of songs on this album and they're
brought to us by her and a gauntlet of
co songwriters and producers who you
might actually be familiar with if
you've been reading a lot of the liner
notes of mainstream contemporary R&B and
hip hop albums over the past several
years
Timbaland Timberlake Mike Dean boots
Noah forty Drake's producer Miguel the
dream hit boy Pharrell surprisingly
enough Caroline pull a check of
chairlift and a lot more I haven't even
mentioned however what is most
interesting on this thing is of course
the music which has received a pretty
warm reception from critics across the
board with a lot of people praising
Beyonce for putting out her most
surprising and ambitious album yet and I
guess you can tag it as that if you want
but I think there are some R&B records
that have come out over the past few
years that are a little more ambitious
Janelle monáe's past few LPS Frank
ocean's channel orange you could even
throw the weekend's trilogy on there if
you want to even though I do agree that
this record is bold for Beyonce I also
find it being kind of parallel to some
other LPS that have come out recently
like nothing was the same
especially on the Drake featuring track
mine I think Beyonce's new LP here is
similarly atmospheric and vast but it
also me Anders a little bit too and has
some kind of dull instrumentals their
tracks on this LP that bring some really
heavy bass and some trap style high hats
too and throw some really inane
self-serious swag on top that sort of
reminds me of tracks from Miley Cyrus's

that have come out recently especially
on tracks like partition which has all
this sexual imagery in the lyrics that
is so vivid it's tantalizing like born
and I don't really think this tracker
tracks on this LP like it are horrible
but I do think they lose their flavor
kind of quick there are high points on
this record that are great in some
moments seem to be really personal and
confessional whether it comes to Beyonce
talking about her life as a famous
singer or as a mother or as jay-z's wife
and like I just said with the sexual
imagery there are a lot of songs on this
thing where beyonce is not afraid to
just get really raunchy and i do think
some of the songs on this LP do bring a
heavier dose of that diva attitude and
female empowerment message that a lot of
people expect from beyonce the opening
track on here pretty hurts is one of my
favorites on this LP and is a bit of a
triumphant ballad about society's
obsession with attaining unattainable
perfection and I think the power of this
song comes down to the line it's the
soul that needs the surgery it's a bit
of a sappy sentiment but there is a hard
truth to it that I like and it does have
a really explosive chorus and Beyonce
follows this really fantastic song this
shot at perfection up with what I think
is is just like an apathetic shrug on
the next track haunted the first half of
this song is just this really
underwhelming airy instrumental and a
bit of spoken word Beyonce says these
record labels are boring and and maybe
they are and she also says out loud that
I'm not gonna make any money off this oh
well but when you're making as much

sort of a worry you can shrug off and
then there's this repeated line about

that's been going on for generations
which also coincidentally makes

there's a second half to this track too

the bass hits on here barely compliment

Beyonce totally sounding like a sloppy

out
something different here with a lot of

like this
Dallas and I really do like the track
even though it is one of the most

and the melody and the instrumentation
on this track is really beautiful it's
gentle it's it's loving like a lullaby
but still I'm pretty neutral on this

that's mostly because of how unfocused a

what this LP suffers from is what I

that is that we have mainstream artists
